Since this is the first part, there is no need to specify any boolean operations. In general, when working with multiple parts, you will need to specify how each part interacts with the preceding parts. The JSON provides four possible boolean operations: NewBodyFeatureOperation, CutFeatureOperation, IntersectFeatureOperation, and JoinFeatureOperation. Instead of using these terms, however, it is often clearer to describe the operations in natural language. For example, instead of CutFeatureOperation, you may write: - Remove this material from the existing body. - Subtract this shape from the existing body. Similarly, instead of IntersectFeatureOperation, you may write: - Create a new body that contains only the intersecting volume between this shape and the existing body. - Combine this shape and the existing body to form a new body containing only the intersecting volume. In general, it is best to use clear and descriptive natural language that describes the intended operation instead of using the technical terms provided by the JSON.</description>
